contentrichtext.text: Five ships of the [[Royal Navy]] have been named '''HMS ''Halcyon'''''. The term ''Halcyon'' originates from the Greek myth of [[Alcyone]] and means golden or marked by peace and prosperity. * The first [[HMS Halcyon (1803)|''Halcyon'']] was the French 16-gun [[brig-sloop]] ''Alcion'', captured in 1803, and broken up 1812. * The second [[HMS Halcyon (1813)|''Halcyon'']] was an 18-gun [[Cruizer class brig-sloop|''Cruizer'' class brig-sloop]] launched in 1813 and wrecked the following year in [[Jamaica]]. * The third [[HMS Halcyon (1894)|''Halcyon'']] was a [[Dryad class torpedo gunboat|''Dryad''-class]] [[torpedo gunboat]] in service from 1894 to 1919. * The fourth [[HMS Halcyon (1916)|''Halcyon'']] was a [[Paddle steamer|paddle]] [[minesweeper (ship)|minesweeper]] in service from 1916 to 1921. * The fifth [[HMS Halcyon (1933)|''Halcyon'']] was a [[Halcyon class minesweeper|''Halcyon''-class]] [[Minesweeper (ship)|minesweeper]]. She was launched in 1933 and sold for scrapping in 1950. ==References== *{{colledge}} {{Shipindex}} {{Italic title prefixed|3}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Halcyon, Hms}} [[Category:Royal Navy ship names]]
